Visualise Singapore trade balance of import and export regionally and at countries level

from year 2020 January to 2022 December

Published

February 18, 2023

Modified

February 20, 2023

1. OVERVIEW

The main focus of this visual analytics assignment is to …

uncover the impact of COVID-19 as well as the global economic and political dynamic in 2022 on Singapore bi-lateral trade (i.e. Import, Export and Trade Balance) by using appropriate analytical visualisation techniques learned in Lesson 6: It’s About Time. Students are encouraged to apply appropriate interactive techniques to enhance user and data discovery experiences.

1.1 Singapore Exports

Key export products -

43% machinery and equipment

19% petroleum

13% chemical products

8% misc manufactured goods.

7% oil bunkers

Main export partners -

China, 15%

China-Hong Kong 12%

Malaysia 11%

Indonesia 8%

United States 6%

Japan 5%

The top exports of Singapore are Integrated Circuits ($62.7B), Refined Petroleum ($27B), Gold ($11.4B), Packaged Medicaments ($9.9B), and Gas Turbines ($9.24B), exporting mostly to China ($42.9B), Hong Kong ($41.7B), United States ($27.6B), Malaysia ($22.9B), and Indonesia ($14.8B). 1

2. R PACKAGE REQUIRED

The following are the packages required for this exercise :

2.1 Load R Packages

pacman::p_load(readxl, ggHoriPlot, ggthemes, ggpubr, lubridate, tidyverse, data.table)

3. DATA

3.1 Acquire Data Source

This study will be based on the statistical time series of a merchandise trade data set that compiled by Enterprise Singapore. The data set is available from the singstat.gov.sg.

  • Download the Excel data set from the link titled “Download all in Excel”.
Highlights of the data set
  1. …

3.2 Import Data

3.2.1 Import attributes data

There are two (2) steps involve, which are import and inspect imported data set.

⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :

read_xlsx( ) - readxl - to read Excel file into a tibble.

select( ) - dplyr - to retain columns specifically, “Data Series” and column names that contain “2019”, “2020”, “2021”, and “2022”. Include “2019” as both Dec and Nov in 2019 are needed to compute the rate for “2020 Jan”.

slice( ) - dplyr - to remove the first row with “Total Merchandise Imports” for trade_import or “Total Merchandise Exports” for trade_export.

problems( ) - readr - to reveal any parsing errors when importing the Excel file.

trade_import <- read_excel("data/merchandiseTrade_region.xlsx",
                           sheet = "T1",
                           range = cell_rows(10:129)) %>%
  select(`Data Series`, contains(c("2019","2020", "2021", "2022"))) %>%
  slice(-1) %>%
  select(-(4:13))
  
problems(trade_import)
trade_export <-  read_xlsx("data/merchandiseTrade_region.xlsx",
                           sheet = "T2",
                           range = cell_rows(10:101)) %>% 
  select(`Data Series`, contains(c("2019", "2020", "2021", "2022"))) %>%
  slice(-1) %>%
  select(-(4:13))

problems(trade_export)

3.3 Wrangle Data

3.3.1 Split variable

⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :

separate( ) - tidyr - to split “Data Series” into 2 new fields “country” and “unit”

str_remove( ) - stringr - to remove parenthesis ” ( ) ” from the “unit” column.

3.3.1.1 Import data

trade_imports <- trade_import %>%
  separate(`Data Series`, c("country", "unit"),
           sep = ' \\(') %>%
  mutate(unit = str_remove(unit, '\\)'))

3.3.1.2 Export data

trade_exports <- trade_export %>%
  separate(`Data Series`, c("country", "unit"),
           sep = ' \\(') %>%
  mutate(unit = str_remove(unit, '\\)'))

3.3.2 Split tables

The data consists of regional (unit consists of “Million Dollars”) and country (unit consists of “Thousand Dollars”) . Hence, two different objects will be created for different content by filter them accordingly.

⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :

str_detect( ) - stringr - to separate data table at countries level and regions level.

slice( ) - dplyr - to remove “Germany, Democratic Republic Of” and “Yemen Democratic” that have 0 value for the entire 2 years.

3.3.2.1 Import data by “Thousand”

trade_importsK <- trade_imports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Thousand")) %>%
  select(-(unit))

3.3.2.2 Import data by “Million”

trade_importsM <- trade_imports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Million")) %>%
  select(-(unit))

3.3.2.3 Export data by “Thousand”

trade_exportsK <- trade_exports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Thousand")) %>%
  select(-(unit))

3.3.2.4 Export data by “Million”

trade_exportsM <- trade_exports %>%
  filter(str_detect(unit, "Million")) %>%
  select(-(unit))

3.3.3 Remove “country” with 0 values

⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :

slice( ) - dplyr - to remove “Germany, Democratic Republic Of” and “Yemen Democratic” that have 0 value for the entire 2 years.

trade_importsK <- trade_importsK %>%
  slice(-20, -64)
trade_exportsK <- trade_exportsK %>%
  slice(-18, -62)

3.3.4 Pivot Tables

3.3.4.1 Pivot imports table

⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :

pivot_longer( ) - tidyr - to pivot data by reducing all year-month columns into a single column. This step is needed to compute the rate.

Arguments :

  • “cols” refers to all columns need to be reshaped except “country”.

  • “names_to” is a new variable name, “temporary” to capture all the year-month of trades.

  • “values_to” is a new variable name, “import” or “export” to store all the traded values.

The code chunk is with reference to cran.r-project2.

import_pl <- trade_importsK %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = "temporary",
               values_to = "import") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)
Show the code 
importM_pl <- trade_importsM %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = "temporary",
               values_to = "import") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)

Remarks :

When using arrange function without first mutate the value with ym function from lubridate package, the period will be sorted by the alphabetical order of the months’ initial character. For example, 2020 Apr be displayed first, follow by 2020 Aug, 2020 Dec, 2020 Feb…

3.3.4.2 Pivot exports table

export_pl <- trade_exportsK %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = 'temporary',
               values_to = "export") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)
Show the code 
exportM_pl <- trade_exportsM %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = !country,
               names_to = "temporary",
               values_to = "export") %>%
  mutate(period = (lubridate::ym(temporary))) %>%
  arrange(country, period) %>%
  select(-temporary) %>%
  relocate(period)

3.3.5 Derive New Variables

3.3.5.1 Derive regionals’ trade balance between exports and imports

Step 1 - Join regionals level dataframes

Show the code 
tradesM<- importM_pl %>% full_join(exportM_pl)

Step 2 - Derive variable

Show the code 
trades_region <- tradesM %>%
  mutate(balance = export-import) %>%
  mutate(diff_balance = balance - shift(balance)) %>%
  mutate(rate = round(
    (diff_balance/shift(balance)),
    digits = 2))

3.3.5.2 Derive countries’ trade balance between exports and imports

Step 1 - Join countries level dataframes

Show the code 
trades <- import_pl %>% full_join(export_pl)

Step 2 - Derive variable

Show the code 
trades <- trades %>%
  mutate(balance = export-import) %>%
  mutate(diff_balance = balance - shift(balance)) %>%
  mutate(rate = round(
    (diff_balance/shift(balance)),
    digits = 2))

3.3.5.3 Derive monthly imports differences

Show the code 
import_trim <- import_pl %>%
  mutate(diff_imp = import - shift(import)) %>%
  mutate(rate_imp = round(
    (diff_imp/shift(import)),
    digits = 2)) %>%
  filter(!period == "2019-12-01" & !period == "2019-11-01")

3.3.5.4 Derive monthly exports differences

Show the code 
export_trim <- export_pl %>%
  mutate(diff_imp = export - shift(export)) %>%
  mutate(rate_imp = round(
    (diff_imp/shift(export)),
    digits = 2)) %>%
  filter(!period == "2019-12-01" & !period == "2019-11-01")

3.3.5.5 Derive “year” and “month” variables

Show the code 
trades_region$month <- factor(month(trades_region$`period`),
                              levels = 1:12, 
                              labels = month.abb, 
                              ordered = TRUE) 
trades_region$year <- year(ymd(trades_region$`period`))

3.3.6 Extract data by Region

3.3.6.1 Africa region

Show the code 
africa <- trades_region %>%
  filter(country == "Africa")

3.3.6.2 America region

Show the code 
america <- trades_region %>%
  filter(country == "America")

3.3.6.3 Asia region

Show the code 
asia <- trades_region %>%
  filter(country == "Asia")

3.3.6.4 Europe region

Show the code 
europe <- trades_region %>%
  filter(country == "Europe")

3.3.6.5 European Union region

Show the code 
eUnion <- trades_region %>%
  filter(country == "European Union")

3.3.6.6 Oceania region

Show the code 
Oceania <- trades_region %>%
  filter(country == "Oceania")

3.3.7 Compute average by month

!!!!! need this? too high level, meaningless to view at region level. Alternative?

Show the code 
hl_africa <- africa %>% 
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avg = mean(balance))


hl_america <- america %>%
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avg = mean(balance))
Show the code 
hl_eUnion <- eUnion %>%
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avg = mean(balance))

3.3.8 Extract countries

3.3.8.1 Countries with trade balance

⇳ Usage of the code chunk below :

drop_na( ) - tidyr - to drop rows that has NA as the “rate” column

Show the code 
trades_trim <- trades %>% drop_na(rate) %>%
  filter(!period == "2019-12-01")

export_xCountries <- trades %>%

eu_test <- eu %>%
  select(1:7) %>%
  gather(key = "variable", value = "value", -country, -period, -rate, -diff_balance, -balance)

germany <- eu_test %>%
  filter(country == "Germany, Federal Republic Of")

4. VISUAL ANALYSIS

4.1 EDA

Show the code 
ggplot(trades_region,
       aes(x = period,
           y = balance)) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = country)) +
  theme(legend.position = "top")

4.2 Cycle Plot

4.2.1 Africa region

africa_plot <- ggplot()  +
  geom_line(data = africa,
            aes(x = year, 
                y = balance, 
                group = month), 
            colour = "black") +
  geom_hline(aes
             (yintercept = avg), 
             data = hl_africa, 
             linetype = 6, 
             colour = "red", 
             size = 0.5) + 
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Trade balance with Africa region, Jan 2020-Dec 2022") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("Trade Balance")

africa_plot

4.2.2 America region

america_plot <- ggplot()  +
  geom_line(data = america,
            aes(x = year, 
                y = balance, 
                group = month), 
            colour = "black") +
  geom_hline(aes
             (yintercept = avg), 
             data = hl_america, 
             linetype = 6, 
             colour = "red", 
             size = 0.5) + 
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Trade balance with America region, Jan 2020-Dec 2022") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("Trade Balance")

america_plot

4.2.x Overview Cycle Plots

ggpubr::ggarrange(africa_plot, 
          america_plot,
          ncol = 1,
          nrow = 2,
          align = "v")

4.3 Visualise Import and Export by Country

germany_cp <- ggplot(data = germany,
                   aes (x = period,
                        y = value)) +
  geom_line(aes
            (color = variable, linetype = variable)) + 
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkred", "steelblue"))

germany_cp

4.4 Horizontal Chart

4.4.1 Trade balance at regional’s level

ggplot() + 
  geom_horizon(aes(period, rate),
               data = trades_region,
               origin = 0,
               horizonscale = c(-15, -5, -1, 0, 1, 5)) +
  scale_fill_hcl(palette = "RdBu") +
  facet_grid(country~.) +
  labs (x = "Period",
        title = "Overview of Singapore Trade Balance with 6 Regions",
        subtitle = "from year January 2020 to December 2022",
        caption = "Data Source : Singstat.gov.sg, 2023") +
  theme_few() +
  theme(plot.margin = margin(0.8, 0.5, 0.8, 0.5, "cm"),
        plot.title = element_text (size = 24, 
                                   colour = "#302f2f",
                                   face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12,
                                     colour = "#424242",
                                     face = "italic",
                                     margin = margin(0,0,10,0)),
        plot.caption = element_text(size = 10,
                                    colour = "#424242",
                                    hjust = 0,
                                    vjust = -2),
    panel.spacing.y = unit(0, "lines"),
    strip.text.y = element_text(size = 8, 
                                angle = 0, 
                                hjust = 0),
    axis.text.y = element_blank(),
    axis.title.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x = element_line(colour = "#969595",
                                linewidth = 0.5),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, angle = 75, hjust = 0, vjust = -0.2),
    axis.title.x = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none"
    ) +
  scale_x_date(expand = c(0,0), 
               date_breaks = "1 month", 
               date_labels = "%b '%y",
               limit = c(as.Date("2020-01-01"),
                         as.Date("2022-12-31"))) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-11-16"), color = "limegreen", size = 1) + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-09-05"), color = "limegreen", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-03-16"), color = "limegreen", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2021-08-23"), color = "limegreen", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-09-19"), color = "orange", size = 1) + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-09-11"), color = "orange", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-08-01"), color = "orange", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-06-22"), color = "orange", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-06-14"), color = "orange", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-05-26"), color = "orange", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-02-24"), color = "orange", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2021-02-24"), color = "purple", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2021-01-07"), color = "purple", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2020-12-01"), color = "purple", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-04-26"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-03-24"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2021-11-26"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2021-10-09"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2021-05-08"), color = "red", size = 1) + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2020-11-09"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2020-06-02"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2020-04-07"), color = "red", size = 1) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2020-02-07"), color = "red", size = 1)

4.4.2 Trade balance at countries’ level

ggplot() + 
  geom_horizon(aes(period, rate),
               data = trades_trim,
               origin = 0,
               horizonscale = c(-15, -5, -1, 0, 1, 5)) +
  scale_fill_hcl(palette = "RdBu") +
  facet_grid(country~.) +
  labs (x = "Period",
        title = "Overview of Singapore Trade Balance with N Countries",
        subtitle = "from year January 2020 to December 2022",
        caption = "Data Source : Singstat.gov.sg, 2023") +
  theme_few() +
  theme(plot.margin = margin(0.8, 0.5, 0.8, 0.5, "cm"),
        plot.title = element_text (size = 24, 
                                   colour = "#302f2f",
                                   face = "bold"),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12,
                                     colour = "#424242",
                                     face = "italic",
                                     margin = margin(0,0,10,0)),
        plot.caption = element_text(size = 10,
                                    colour = "#424242",
                                    hjust = 0,
                                    vjust = -2),
    panel.spacing.y = unit(0, "lines"),
    strip.text.y = element_text(size = 8, 
                                angle = 0, 
                                hjust = 0),
    axis.text.y = element_blank(),
    axis.title.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.x = element_line(colour = "#969595",
                                linewidth = 0.5),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10, angle = 75, hjust = 0, vjust = -0.2),
    axis.title.x = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "none"
    ) +
  scale_x_date(expand = c(0,0), 
               date_breaks = "1 month", 
               date_labels = "%b '%y",
               limit = c(as.Date("2020-01-01"),

  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-09-05"), color = "limegreen", size = 1) +

  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2022-02-24"), color = "orange", size = 1) +

Remarks :

Click on the accordion to view the incidents that may explain the rate of trade balance fluctuation.

Date of Homeland Incidents
2022 Apr 26

Singapore Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) Orange to Yellow3

Further easing community policies (safe distancing, group size limit and events’ capacity limit are lifted) and border measures.
2022 Mar 24

Singapore Easing Community SMMs and Border Measures

Singapore Tasks Force eased the community Safe Management Measures (SMM) and border measures.
2021 Nov 26

OMICRON VARIANT OF COVID-19

On 26 Nov 2021, the World Health Organisation (WHO) announced the Omicron variant discovery of COVID-19.

  • While there was some dip to the stock market prices, due to lack of information on the virus, the impact seems to be lower than the Delta and Alpha variant of the virus for most companies.
2021 Oct 09

CAUTIOUS RE-OPENING WITH ENDEMIC COVID-19

Since then, the nation has acknowledged that the Zero-Covid strategy is no longer feasible due to highly infectious variants formed.

  • It has engaged a cautions re-opening strategy to enable Singaporeans to resume their lives, participate in social activities, open the borders and revive the economy.

  • One such example would be the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) which allowed fully-vaccinated Singaporean citizens and permanent residents to return to Singapore without quarantine.

  • On 9 Oct 2021, it was announced that Singapore would open up more VTLs with other countries, including South Korea and the United States.

  • This saw some rise in the stock market prices, especially companies who stand to gain most such as Singapore Airlines and SATS.
2021 May 08

DELTA WAVE OF COVID-19

By May 2021, the Delta variant of COVID-19 had widely spread, causing several clusters across the nation.

  • The re-opening efforts put forth by the Government were heldback, Singapore reverted back to Phase 2 from 8 May, which was subsequently tightened to Phase 2 Heightened Alert from 16 May.

  • This tightening of measures caused the stock market prices to dip.
2020 Nov 09

National Vaccination Campaign

Pfizer and BioNTech SE announced a vaccine candidate that has demonstrated evidence of efficacy against COVID-19.

  • Since Dec 2020, the National Vaccination Campaign commenced and in late 2021, Singapore became the world’s most-vaccinated country, with more than 85% of its total population fully-vaccinated.
2020 Jun 02

Eased of circuit breaker

Enters its first phase of reopening, where businesses and activities are progressively allowed to resume, giving rise to some semblance of normalcy.
2020 Apr 07

Circuit breaker

Introduced the Circuit Breaker period, where citizens practised enhanced social distancing and isolation.

  • Workplaces and schools closed and most shops shuttered.

  • Businesses were badly impacted by the drop in footfall and consumption.

  • However, the stock market seem to be recovering from the crash in March.

  • One reason could be the implementation of the Budgets the Government has dedicated to support Singaporeans and businesses in the battle against COVID-19, which amounted close to $100 billion.

  • Secondly, businesses were also adapting to the change in consumer patterns through contactless digital systems, which were well-received.
2020 Feb 07

Initial wave of Covid-19

Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) to orange, signalling that the disease is severe and there is widespread transmission from unknown sources.

  • This is highest level ever reached since the SARS outbreak in 2003.

  • The severity of the pandemic caused panic and uncertainty amongst business and citizens.

  • More countries were also entering a lockdown state to contain the spread, disrupting global trade flows which exacerbated the market.

  • Hence, spurring on the COVID-19 financial crash in March 2020, which not only impacted Singapore but all major stock markets as well.

  • The March 2020 COVID-19 crash was a short-lived bear market, and in April 2020 stock markets re-entered a bull market.
Date of global affairs and high economic damages disasters
2022 Sep

Magnitude 7.6 earthquake in Papua New Guinea

Power supply facilities across the region were damaged.
2022 Aug

Severe drought in China
